awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Optimal Delivery of Augmented Information Services Over Next-Generation Cloud Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Moving data and services from local computers into the cloud has been one of the major trends in information technology over the past years. This trend has upended the computer industry, and provides benefits, for example, in terms of more efficient use of computing resources (which can now be shared by different users) and centralized software updates (which increase security).  In a related trend, most information such as video is now stored in the cloud, and delivered to the users on demand, replacing local storage methods such as DVDs and DVRs. Augmented information (AgI) services, an important extension of that trend, combine content delivery and computation, for example, when the original video source data are processed on their way to the destination to create augmented reality, telepresence, real-time surveillance, or industrial automation. This project investigates how such joint communication and computation can be done in the most efficient way in terms of energy, cost, or other criteria that might be important to the consumer or provider. 

Transmitting information over large distances is usually via multiple "hops", i.e., it goes from the source via several intermediate nodes to the destination. For example, the information could be routed from a source in Los Angeles via Denver, Dallas, Atlanta, to New York. The necessary processing could be done at any of those nodes, or might be distributed among different nodes with different associated costs. Since processing can make the files larger or smaller (e.g., transcoding functions), this also has an impact on the communication cost to the next nodes. This project investigates the fundamental performance limits of this type of network and develops practical algorithms that can do the routing and assignment of processing resources in an efficient way. 

The goals of the project are to: (i) develop a universal model for AgI services, as a generalization of traditional information services; (ii) formalize the AgI service distribution problem (AgI-SDP) for the quasi-static case, where placement of information and assignment of resources changes only slowly and provide a complexity classification for each major service class and design fast approximation algorithms for the AgI-SDP in its different categories; (iii) develop formulations and algorithms that dynamically adjust the configuration of AgI services in response to unknown changes in cloud network conditions and service demands; and (iv) validate the algorithms by experimentation on testbeds at Bell Labs.

The services covered by the AgI model range from network services (e.g., 5G network slices) to automation services (e.g., smart buildings, industrial automation, smart transportation), to augmented experience services (e.g., virtual reality, immersive video), and efficient design of such systems thus has great impact on the economy, ecology (energy savings) and user experience of a wide variety of services. Optimization of such distributed systems also enhance the robustness of computation and communication infrastructure to disruptions from natural disasters and other events.  The project includes a strong outreach and education program including having undergraduates and graduate students perform experiments at the project collaborator's state-of-the-art laboratory at Bell Labs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Applications and Motivation

Next-generation augmented information (AgI) services, such as system automation (e.g., smart homes/transportation/manufacturing) and consumer experiences (virtual/augmented reality), will shape the future of people’s life. Their real-time interactive and multi-resource intensive nature also accelerates the need for distributed compute platforms with unprecedented storage, computation, and communication requirements, pushing the convergence of next-generation networks and distributed cloud technologies. Furthermore, it imposes new requirements on the management of networks that performs end-to-end optimization and dynamic control of the infrastructure to achieve higher levels of compute, communication, and caching (3C) integration.

Studied Topics

This award investigated several topics that centered around the development of dynamic control algorithms for next-generation computing networks and applications. As the first step, it developed a dynamic control algorithm for general mobile edge computing (MEC) systems, extending the approaches designed for cloud computing networks. In addition, the project extend the basic algorithm and propose dedicated solutions for three classes of applications attracting increasing attention and having multiple applications (e.g., autonomous driving, multi-player gaming, and augmented reality):

1)  delay-constrained services, in which each data packet has a strict deadline by which the contained information must be delivered or it becomes useless;

2)  multicast-cast services, in which each data packet can be shared and simultaneously consumed by multiple users/devices;

3)  data-intensive services, in which the multiple data streams must be processed together in order to produce enhanced experiences.

Finally, the project developed a unified cloud network flow framework to design control policies for next generation networks, encompassing network-layer operations (e.g., packet processing/transmission/replication), as well as physical-layer decisions (e.g., compute/communication/storage resource allocation).

Methodology and Novelty

While there are many existing network control technologies, they have challenges in supporting the delivery of emerging AgI services, due to two reasons: 1) they are designed for traditional computer networks, while the considered underlying infrastructure is highly distributed, dynamic, and heterogenous, 2) the do not consider the increasingly unique and stringent requirements raised by the emerging applications mentioned above. To address these challenges, the proposed solution is a combination of stochastic control theory (e.g., Lyapunov optimization, Markov decision process), information theory (e.g., network stability region), and network optimization methods (e.g., max-flow/min-cost flow problems).

One main contribution of our work has been the design of novel queuing systems dedicated for each class of AgI services. For example, lifetime queues to hold packets based on lifetime (i.e., the remaining time until the deadline) and duplication status queues to hold packets based on duplication status (i.e., the current destination node set) for delay-constrained and mixed-cast services, respectively, were proposed. These are key properties that shall drive decision making to enhance the performance of service delivery.

Outcomes 

The outcomes of the project are summarized as follows: for each class (delay-constrained/mixed-cast/data-intensive) of AgI services, the project:

1)  Proposed a service model to characterize its unique requirement, i.e., packets with hard deadlines, packets with multiple destinations, and service directed acyclic graph (service DAG), respectively.

2)  Established a novel queuing system to accommodate the packets and derive/design its dynamics, i.e., lifetime queues, duplication status queues, and paired packet queues, respectively.

3)  Developed dynamic control algorithms, targeting queue stability, and the optimization of additional objectives (e.g., overall operational cost).

4)  Characterized the network stability region to support these emerging services, with generalized flow conservation laws (e.g., flow conservation with lifetime and multiple destinations).

5)  Analyzed the performance of the proposed algorithm, and illustrated the interplay between the performance metrics (e.g., delay-cost tradeoff).

6)  Analyzed the complexity of the proposed algorithm, and designed heuristic variants with reduced complexity while minimizing the performance loss.

 

Broader impact

The results of this research will enable the design and operation of more efficient augmented information services. Given the diverse nature of applications, the results will impact fields ranging from virtual reality, to autonomous cars, to industry 4.0. The project has kept close contact with US industry and provided advanced knowledge for their product development. The results of the research have been disseminated through journal and conference papers, journals at tutorials, and are part of graduate courses at USC. The work has also enabled PhD students to work in an interdisciplinary way combining knowledge and challenges from different areas of communications and information processing.
